item.title: 英国为核电被视为 "绿色 "扫清债券市场道路
item.description: 英国将首次允许将绿色债券销售所得资金用于资助核电，这在环保人士中一直被视为有争议的举措。【原文：The UK will for the first time allow money generated from green-bond sales to go toward financing nuclear power, taking a step long seen as controversial among environmentalists.】

item.title: 暴风雨导致中西部停电，威胁感恩节出行
item.description: 在美国准备迎接一年中最繁忙的旅行日之一--感恩节假期前夕之际，大雪和狂风正在美国中西部蔓延，引发停电以及潜在的地面和空中延误。【原文：Snowy and blustery conditions are spreading across the US Midwest, triggering power outages and potential ground and air delays as the US prepares for one of its busiest travel days of the year – the eve of the Thanksgiving holiday.】

item.title: 监督机构称，英国 14 亿英镑的电动汽车里程税将打击需求
item.description: 根据英国预算措施，英国的电动汽车和插电式混合动力汽车车主将被征收每英里付费税，而汽车制造商必须完成电动汽车的销售任务，这可能会抑制需求。【原文：Britain’s electric and plug-in hybrid vehicle owners will be subject to a pay-per-mile tax, under UK budget measures tipped to dent demand at a time when carmakers must meet an EV sales mandate.】

item.title: Brad Lander 建议纽约养老基金抛弃贝莱德
item.description: 纽约最大的养老金管理公司正面临不信任。即将离任的主计长布拉德-兰德（Brad Lander）建议纽约市放弃贝莱德，因为贝莱德在将气候因素纳入投资策略方面做得不够。【原文：New York’s largest pension manager is facing a show of no confidence. Outgoing Comptroller Brad Lander has recommended that the city drop BlackRock because it’s not doing enough to factor climate into its investment strategies.】

item.title: 纽约市兰德建议放弃贝莱德 420 亿美元的授权
item.description: 纽约市主计长布拉德-兰德（Brad Lander）正敦促该市三家养老基金放弃贝莱德公司（BlackRock Inc.【原文：New York City Comptroller Brad Lander is urging three of the city’s pension funds to drop BlackRock Inc. because of “inadequate” climate plans, the latest move to penalize investment firms for failing to tackle global warming.】

item.title: 欧盟议会支持将森林砍伐法规推迟一年实施
item.description: 欧洲议会支持将一项遏制全球森林砍伐的里程碑式法律推迟一年实施，并寻求放宽合规要求，这些要求引起了人们对该措施的行政负担和对贸易影响的担忧。【原文：The European Parliament supported a one-year delay to a landmark law to curb deforestation across the world and sought to soften compliance requirements that have raised concerns about the measure’s administrative burden and impact on trade.】

item.title: 随着联邦支持减少，加州投资廉价热泵
item.description:
州政府将拨款 1 亿多美元，用于创造对租房者和低收入居民负担得起的节能技术的需求。【原文：

The state is allocating more than $100 million to create demand for energy-efficient technologies that renters and low-income residents can afford. 

】

item.title: 施耐德说：美国即将出现的电力紧张将削弱人工智能能力
item.description: 随着数据中心用电需求的激增，以及电网老化和脆弱的冰冷现实，美国将在本十年面临一场潜在的电力危机。【原文：The US faces a potential electricity crisis this decade as a surge in demand to power data centers bumps into the cold reality of aged and vulnerable grids.】

item.title: 中国建造大型风力涡轮机的速度将放缓
item.description: 据行业高管称，由于技术障碍，中国制造商在未来几年建造更大型风力涡轮机的竞赛预计将放缓。【原文：The race among Chinese manufacturers to build ever-larger wind turbines is expected to slow due to technical hurdles in the coming years, according to industry executives.】

item.title: 日本考虑帮助南非资助能源改革
item.description: 日本正在与南非就可能帮助该国为能源部门重组提供资金一事进行谈判。【原文：Japan is in talks with South Africa over potentially helping the country finance the reorganization of its energy sector.】

item.title: 卡尼的石油出口策略取决于修复破碎的碳市场
item.description: 加拿大总理马克-卡尼（Mark Carney）表示，加拿大政府正在与阿尔伯塔省谈判一项协议，为未来建设一条通往加拿大西海岸的新石油管道 "创造必要条件"。【原文：Prime Minister Mark Carney said his government is negotiating an agreement with Alberta that “creates necessary conditions” for the future construction of a new oil pipeline to Canada’s west coast.】

item.title: 特斯拉联合创始人斯特劳贝尔的电池初创公司 Redwood 裁员数十人
item.description: 特斯拉公司联合创始人JB Straubel的电池回收公司Redwood Materials Inc.裁员数十人，因为这家初创公司缩减了一些雄心勃勃的项目，重新专注于开发电网规模的电池需求。【原文：Tesla Inc. co-founder JB Straubel’s battery recycling firm Redwood Materials Inc. cut dozens of jobs as the startup scales back some of its ambitious projects to refocus on tapping into demand for grid-scale batteries.】

item.title: 气候峰会正在按设计运行：效果不佳
item.description:
未来人们将如何记住 COP30？Bloomberg Green的Jennifer Dlouhy和Akshat Rathi在 "零 "播客中进行了讨论。【原文：

How will COP30 be remembered in years to come? Bloomberg Green’s Jennifer Dlouhy and Akshat Rathi discuss on the Zero podcast.

】

item.title: 人工智能如何帮助降低野火风险
item.description: 电线引燃树木是破坏性火灾的主要原因。那么电力公司该怎么办？使用人工智能指导修剪树木。【原文：Powerlines igniting trees is a major cause of destructive fires. So what’s a utility to do? Trim the trees using AI guidance.】

item.title: 葡萄酒需求下降，法国斥资 1.5 亿美元拔除葡萄树
item.description: 法国是世界顶级葡萄酒生产国之一，将拨款 1.3 亿欧元（1.5 亿美元）帮助农民拔除更多的葡萄树，因为气候变化、全球需求疲软和贸易战使这一行业遭受重创。【原文：France, one of the world’s top winemakers, will disburse €130 million ($150 million) to help farmers uproot more vines in a sector hit hard by climate change, weak global demand and trade wars.】

item.title: 大规模野火责任促使公用事业公司使用人工智能阻止火灾
item.description:
电力公司正在求助于能够在火灾发生前发现脆弱树木并绘制高风险区域地图的技术公司。【原文：

Power companies are turning to tech firms that can spot fragile trees and map high-risk areas before fires start.

】

item.title: 筹集 10 亿澳元后，亚洲国际投资银行考虑发行第三期适应性债券
item.description: 亚洲基础设施投资银行（Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank）在前两次发行债券筹集到 10 亿澳元（6.45 亿美元）资金后，正在考虑发行第三次债券的计划，以资助帮助发展中国家建设抵御气候变化能力的项目。【原文：The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank is considering a plan to issue a third bond to finance projects that help developing countries build resilience against climate change, after raising A$1 billion ($645 million) in two previous offerings.】

item.title: 中国太阳能行业应对产能过剩，行业领袖呼吁耐心等待
item.description: 中国太阳能制造商必须耐心解决供过于求和价格竞争等深层次问题，这些问题已造成整个行业的亏损。【原文：China’s solar manufacturers must be patient in resolving deep-rooted problems of oversupply and price competition that have caused sector-wide losses, senior company executives warned at an industry conference.】

item.title: BII 与 FirstRand 成立价值 1.5 亿美元的能源转型基金
item.description: 英国政府的发展金融部门和南非的 FirstRand 有限公司成立了一个 1.5 亿美元的基金，提供贷款资助非洲碳密集型产业的公司向使用更环保的生产方法转型。【原文：The UK government’s development-finance arm and South Africa’s FirstRand Ltd. have formed a $150 million facility to offer loans to fund the transition of companies in carbon-intensive industries in Africa to the use of greener production methods.】

item.title: 预报将有更多降雨，东南亚部分地区遭受致命洪灾
item.description: 暴雨在东南亚各地引发了致命的洪灾，农作物受损，游客受困，预计到下周初还会有更多的暴雨。【原文：Heavy rainfall has unleashed deadly floods across Southeast Asia, damaging crops and stranding tourists, with more downpours expected into early next week.】

item.title: 气候风险工程师在灾难来临前为企业做好准备
item.description: 本周末在南非举行的二十国集团（G20）峰会证明，在包括气候在内的一些问题上，没有美国的参与，世界正在向前迈进。但它也表明，全球多边秩序正在分裂。【原文：This weekend’s G20 summit in South Africa proved the world is moving on without the US on some issues, including climate. But it also showed the global multilateral order is splintering.】

item.title: 瑞士信贷校友帮助资助巴哈马新建碳设施
item.description: 一家由前瑞士信贷银行家成立的精品私人信贷公司已同意提供贷款机制，以支持巴哈马的一项新碳计划。【原文：A boutique private-credit firm set up by former Credit Suisse bankers has agreed to provide a lending facility to support a new carbon program in the Bahamas.】

item.title: X-Energy 为先进核反应堆设计融资 7 亿美元
item.description: 由亚马逊公司（Amazon.com Inc. ）支持的先进核技术公司 X-Energy LLC 从简街集团（Jane Street Group）领导的投资者那里筹集了约 7 亿美元，用于将其小型反应堆商业化。【原文：X-Energy LLC, an advanced nuclear technology company backed by Amazon.com Inc., raised some $700 million from investors led by Jane Street Group to commercialize its small reactor.】

item.title: 在 COP30 会议上，原住民的要求不仅仅是口头承诺
item.description:
在峰会结束时，土著团体成员在土地指定和直接融资等一些优先事项上取得了具体进展。【原文：

Members of Indigenous groups left the summit with concrete progress on some of their priorities, including land designation and direct finance.

】

item.title: 气候会议的人文内幕— 缔约方会议回忆集
item.description: 缔约方大会每年一次将数千人聚集在一起，目的是推动应对气候变化的斗争。这是一场宣泄的盛会，在这里，超技术性的外交谈话占据了中心位置。但是，当大量的人聚集在一个地方时，往往也会有眼泪、欢笑和愤怒。【原文：COP talks bring together thousands of people once a year with a goal to advance the fight against climate change. They’re cathartic events where hyper-technical diplomatic talk takes center stage. But as is often the case when very large numbers of humans congregate in a single place, there are also tears, laughs and anger.】

item.title: 废料堆积如山，印尼大型镍厂削减产量
item.description: 据熟悉内情的人士透露，印尼最重要镍矿产地的一家中方控股工厂正在削减产量，因为其尾矿场已接近饱和，这凸显了该行业日益严峻的废物管理挑战。【原文：A majority Chinese-owned plant at Indonesia’s most important nickel site is cutting back production as its tailings site is nearly full, according to people familiar with the matter, highlighting the industry’s growing waste management challenge.】

item.title: 保险公司有了从气候风险中赚钱的新方法
item.description:
企业不仅要向保险公司支付保险金，以便在灾难发生时为其提供支持，而且还要支付咨询费，以便从一开始就防止损失的发生。【原文：

Companies aren’t just paying insurers to backstop them if a disaster strikes, they’re shelling out consulting fees to help prevent losses in the first place.

】

item.title: 巴黎会议十年后，气候外交的目的在于自救
item.description:
在巴西举行的 COP30 峰会的成果保持了多边主义的活力，同时勉强推进了应对全球变暖的承诺。【原文：

The outcome of the COP30 summit in Brazil kept multilateralism alive while barely pushing forward the promise of combatting global warming.

】

item.title: 英国将延长电动汽车补贴以抵消预算案中的增税措施
item.description: 英国政府将增加对电动汽车的补贴，以缓解下周预算案中针对电动汽车的增税措施。【原文：The UK government will increase subsidies for electric vehicles as it seeks to mitigate a tax rise that’s expected to target the cars at next week’s budget.】

item.title: COP30 气候协议须知
item.description: 经过两周的洪水、火灾、抗议和咖啡助兴的深夜谈判，COP30 已落下帷幕。该协议缺乏雄心壮志，令许多国家感到沮丧。今天的时事通讯将介绍今年谈判的六大收获，以及世界在减排和适应更热地球方面的努力方向。【原文：After two weeks of flood, fire, protests and coffee-fueled late-night negotiations, COP30 has reached a close. The deal left many nations frustrated with its lack of ambition. Today’s newsletter covers the six key takeaways from this year’s talks and where it leaves the world in its efforts to cut emissions and adapt to a hotter planet.】
